row.cell: “Andernacht” [section title] “Twilightʼs mists are gathering grey” [“Andernacht”] [poem, Friendshipʼs Offering text], with “We have wound a weary way” [“First Sketch of ‘Andernach’”] [poem, MS IA, g.2 / MS IX text] associated in noteRuskin, Works, 2:347
“What is it that makes the very heart leap”(prose)
“What is it that makes the very heart leap within you” [“Andernacht”] [essay]Ruskin, Works, 2:373

“Ehrenbreitstein” [section title] “Oh warmly down the sunbeams fell” [“Ehrenbreitstein”] [poem, Poems (1850) text] Ruskin, Works, 2:347–48 Ruskin, Works, 2:360 n. 1, attached by the editors to the end of the “St. Goar” poem, for which the draft, they say, “contains at this point the . . . prose passage.” In manuscript, however, this prose has no association with “St. Goar”; it follows, rather, the poem, “Oh the morn looked bright over hill and dale,” in which lines 8 and 27 identify what the prose passage calls “our entrance into the narrow dell above mentioned.”
“It is said that French will carry you all over Europe”(prose)
“It is said that French will carry you all over Europe” [“Ehrenbreitstein”] [essay]Ruskin, Works, 2:373–74

n/a, but "100" and "925" appear in margin next to drawings (p. 66r)

cell.ref: “Smiling from those bright rays kiss” [“Heidelberg”] [poem, part 1]

row.cell: Ruskin, Works, 2:361–62. In n. 1 on p. 361, the editors print what they represent as draft lines in MS VIII, dropped from the MS IX. The reverse is true, however; these lines are not found in MS VIII, but in MS IX. In other words, if the reader restores the lines in n. 1 to their place where annotated by the editors, the poem reads as it appears in fair copy, MS IX. When one makes this correction to the text as edited in the Library Edition, the 30 lines comprising “Smiling from those bright rays kiss” can be recognized as draft for lines 19–48 of the fair copy—counting, that is, the lines that the editors inexplicably drop into a note on p. 361.
1083–1155 (the title mistakenly included in line numbering)

“It is said that French will carry you over all Europe” [“Ehrenbreitstein”] [prose]
